citation.article-title: Helicobacter pullorum sp. nov.-genotype and phenotype of a new species isolated from poultry and from human patients with gastroenteritis.

p.s: Description of Helicobacter pullorum sp. nov.
(pullorum, from Latin noun pullus, chicken; after source of first isolation)
Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, gently curved, slender, rod-shaped cells, 3-4 μm in length.
Cells carry an unsheathed monopolar flagellum.
Typical darting motility.
Microaerophilic.
Grows microaerobically at 37 °C and 42 °C.
No growth under aerobic conditions or anaerobically [on TMAO medium].
Colonies pinpoint, non-pigmented, translucent and α-haemolytic on 5 % horse blood agar.
Produces oxidase and reduces nitrate.
Most strains (14/16) produce catalase.
No production of urease or alkaline phosphatase.
No hydrolysis of indoxyl acetate.
Resistant to cephalothin and cefoperazone.
The G + C content of the genomic DNA by thermal denaturation is 34-35 mol %.
A 447 bp PCR amplicon is specifically generated using the primers 5' ATG AAT GCT AGT TGT TGT CAG 3' and 5' GAT TGG CTC CACTTC ACA 3' and an annealing temperature of 60 °C.
Isolated from broiler and layer chickens, with or without vibrionic hepatitis.
Also isolated from humans with gastrointestinal disease.
Formal description of the type strain
NCTC 12824T is the type strain of H. pullorum.
This strain conforms to the description of the species given above.
Its G+C content is 34-5 mol%.
It was isolated from a healthy broiler chicken in Switzerland.
Three additional strains have been deposited with the National Collection of Type Cultures : NCTC 12825, NCTC 12826 and NCTC 12827.
